intro: Anemia spannagelii, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial with succulent, fleshy leaves that store water, aiding its survival in dry conditions. The plant produces yellow flowers that bloom in the spring, followed by small, hairy seed capsules that disperse via the wind. Its root system is extensive and deep, allowing it to access moisture from deeper soil layers. Anemia spannagelii is adapted to high temperatures and poor soil conditions, making it a hardy species in harsh environments.
